reviewText:
This game really does have a special place in my heart. Now, I'm reviewing this on the stance that I have played the first two, and replayed them again and again before purchasing this game. Zombie Army Trilogy is a remake/sequel to the surprisingly successful Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army games. This game, while containing remade versions of the first two games, includes and entirely new third chapter. I shall go over the pros and cons, and the final virdict.

Pros~
- The graphics are VERY nice, and compliment the world and atmosphere greatly.
- The soundtrack is very likeable. It reminds me of those 80s snuff horror films with the synth soundtracks.
- Gunplay is fantastic. This was a given with a Sniper Elite game.
- This is a fantastic co-op game. Team up with up to 4 of your friends to take down the zombie menace!
- Kill Hitler. Zombified. If that's not a selling point, I don't know what is.
- You can now, unlike the others, play as a female.
- For some reason, that I'm NOT complaining about, you can play as the Left 4 Dead characters. M'kay.
- Hours and HOURS of replayability. I went back and was constantly discovering things I didn't see.
- The brand new Horde mode. Fight of waves of the undead until your eventual downfall!

Cons ~
- The AI is not very smart. The only enemy that will give you any REAL trouble is the Heavys.
- Voice acting and story is mediocre at best.
- The full price. $44.99 is not what this game is worth.

Final Virdict: 8.5/10
Zombie Army Trilogy offers a fun game to play with your friends when you feel like being a hero and taking down both the Nazi and the Zombie regimes. While still suffering from bugs, I personally recommend this game. It's definately fun, and you won't be disappointed, but it's not worth the $44.99 price tag. I suggest picking it up when it is on sale. Have a great day, and thanks for reading!

reviewText:
A really solid and enjoyable shooter that's given me many hours of entertainment and made me scream every time a zombie moved awkwardly and cost me my fifty kill combo.

The game has a very nice selection of weapons to choose from. Obviously the focus is the rifles, of which there are plenty of varieties, from the British Lee Enfield which has ten rounds in its magazine and is suited to people like me who can't aim very well, to the powerful Mosin Nagant which packs a punch at the cost of a small mag. The only secondary weapons I have found to be of real worth are shotguns and the panzerfaust however; the submachine guns feel too difficult to control, seem very weak (I seem to pepper even the most basic zombie with half a mag and it won't go down) and are infuriatingly prone to costing you a good combo. At close range you want your pistol out but occasionally they can feel a little lacklustre too, the main exception being the Webley revolver, which destroys zombies nicely.

The mechanics are fun, challenging and rewarding, especially if you go on the highest difficulty where you really have to adjust your aim to counter the wind and gravity. It's also great when you land a perfect grenade and obliterate fifteen zombies at once, and mildly amusing to watch a few of them stagger around without a head. The x-ray kill cam shots are brutal and make me very happy when I see my bullets mangling skulls and popping organs like balloons.

The secrets are very well hidden, so much so that I've begun to doubt their existence entirely. This is a good thing as secrets are meant to be challenging to find.

Enemies offer a range of difficulties for you to overcome. Hordes of zombies give plenty of opportunity for massive combos, assuming you can aim better than I can, which shouldn't be hard. The screaming kamikazes that occasionally charge you can prove quite useful in taking out said hordes.The one thing I hate in terms of the enemies is the sniper zombies, who fly around far to liberally and laugh at you in a trolltastic way every time they land a shot and you don't get them. It makes it all the more rewarding when you plug them in the head at 100 plus metres. The slow but purposeful zombie elites provide a target that's just right in terms of toughness: get to close and you're screwed. You may be out of range but it will certainly take more than one headshot to bring him down.

In terms of horde mode, which is like Nazi Zombies from Call of Duty except third person and a bit harder, don't do it alone unless you're actually half decent at the game. You will get eaten. If you're me, the snipers will troll you to madness. Bring friends who can aim.

In conclusion, give Rebellion some money and shoot zombies. You will have a lot of fun. This is also the first game since Wolfenstein 3D that I know about that sends you on a mission to kill Hitler. Why have no other developers capitalised on this simple yet absolutely brilliant concept?

reviewText:
A solid 8.5/10

Pros:

*For me, some beautiful locations and set pieces to admire as I fight back the WWII era undead.
*Varied enemy types, a big plus.
*Deaths never felt cheap, I always died becasue of my stupidity or laziness.
*Well optimnized, ran flawlessly at 1080p.
*Lot of detail and love went into some of the maps/layouts which were a blast to play on.
*Graphics are great, some great lighting effects to set the atmosphere and tone of the game.
*Varied weapons had their own distinct feel.
*Bullet cam, never really got old (Can change the frequency in menu options)
*Lengthy campaign and no sight of microtransactions (Which says alot)
*Entertaiing boss battles or boss sequences.
*25ft Hitler showdown at end of game.
*Got the game for $10 on sale.

Cons:

*No weapon upgrades or progression.
*No detailed stastics of how much damage weapons do compared to others.
*Little to no story or but the name of the game tells you what youre in for.
*Highest difficulty coupled with some though fights they put you in can be a pain to get through.
*Had troble finding a multiplayer game on several occasions.

All in all, I had alot of fun with this game, I would give it a solid 8.5/10.  Def worth a buy if its on sale.

reviewText:
I would not recommend this game.

Pros:
- Sniper simulation is engaging
- Visuals are slick

Cons:
- The campaign missions are long and don't save progress within an episode. Each one takes about an hour to complete.
-The campaign is boring. The whole first episode introduces all enemy types in the first of six episodes.
-The horde mode only has 5 maps across 3 games. This isn't enough maps to play on.
-The game's mechanics make it so that you rarely use the sniper simulation (bullet drop happens at distances further than you tend to engage zombies at)
-The lack of stealth makes sniping at range an unlikely event.
-The price I paid ($15) is too much for the amount and quality of content provided. More maps for horde would rectify this.

Bottom line:
I got more value out of Killing Floor.

reviewText:
Its a very fun zombie shooter, and since it has 3 campaigns i think its DEFINITELY worth 50 bucks
also............. L4D3 CONFIRMED!?

heres some math to tell you if the games worth the price...

zombie army 1 and zombie army 2 are both 16.99
16.99 + 16.99 = 33.98
lets say they released the third game for 16.99
that would be 50.97 for all 3 games but since zombie army 3 is new it would be 21.99 at the lowest so
33.98 + 21.99 = 55.97
so that means that for 49.99 that's a good price because you save more money than you would if they sold zombie army 3 separately!

now lets do some more math but this time lets add the cost of zombie army 1 and 2 if the ones sold separately were remastered as well!
since the zombie army 1 and 2 are remastered in this trilogy lets say the zombie army 1 and 2 sold separately on steam are remastered. that would bump the price up from 16.99 to 21.99 so lets do our math over again and say
zombie army 1, 2 and 3 are both 21.99
21.99 x 3 = 65.97
so if all 3 games were sold separately on steam and zombie army 1 and 2 were sold as remastered versions it would cost you 15.98 more than this.

now lets do the cost if it was a bundle
lets say steam bundled the games. since bundles are usually a little bit cheaper lets say you save 4.99.
65.97 - 4.99 = 60.98
but like we said for the non-bundled and remastered versions, you pay 15.98 more. so even if the bundle let you save 10.99 you still pay more.

I am 90% sure that 49.99 is a great price for Zombie Army Trilogy so im going to rate the price 9/10 if you buy it new

Now lets have a little fun
I bought this on sale for 16.99
I saved 33.00 on this trilogy
I saved 38.98 if all games were sold separately
I saved 48.98 if all games were sold separately and zombie army 1 and 2 were remastered
I saved 43.98 if I bought the bundle (if the bundle let me save an extra 4.99)

this is more of a price review instead of a game review, i know lol

reviewText:
I read all kinds of reviews saying this was way better than any Nazi zombie game out there. Saying it blew COD Nazi zombies out of the water. No. This game is really cool if you like Sniper Elite 3, then take that and turn it into a zombie game. That's what this is.

It's a pretty cool game so far but the aiming is super annoying. Zombies right in front of me, I shoot point blank in the face, and it hits them in the stomach, or flies over their shoulder. Then there are these boss zombies who I can only assume have indestructble metals in their head because they can for some reason take 50 shots from my rifle straight to the face. Then for some reason my ability to kick zombies seems stronger than all my weapons combined. There is nothing overly special about this game.

Like I said, I really enjoy Sniper Elite 3, so I do enjoy this game, it's just not as good as everyone is claiming it is.

reviewText:
I hate Nazis and i love to shoot them up. Now imagine  Zombie nazis, This game!
become an ultimate Nazi-Zombie slayer!

I love this game, the combat from the sniper shooting Mechanic (Well basically this is Sniper Elite with Zombies) to the usage of explosives, It's all Satisfying. And don't forget the World War 2 era themed germany, It's well designed and creepy enough with Bodies and human organs everywhere  and the fogs surrounding the area. The gameplay is not as fast as Left 4 dead's gameplay mechanics, also we play the game in Third person Perspective which is good, giving more feels to your character. The Zombies are slower (yeah, they're walking), but slow doesn't mean that they're easy to kill and harmless, You must shoot them in the head or they'll just ressurect in front of you, And... The amount of zombie here is massive, so always prepare your mines and grenades because you don't want to end up surrounded by them. Most zombie games are virus-related, but here, the zombies are more of a ritual creature, and with the Gothic WW2 germany surroundings, the vibe is creepy and scary.
Also, gotta love the music of the game, it's good and catchy. The retro electronic music fits perfectly in the game.
I recommend this game, It's fun to play alone and much better in co-op, Cheers..

reviewText: This would have to be the best Zombie game i have played. I am exceptionally fond of the sniping, with the ability to calm your breathing and take precise shots. The other weapon load outs are good. I miss the abilty to hack zombies apart with a machete or other melee weapon but, most enemies are dead before they get to you if you manage your sniper rifle ammo correctly and make the shots you need to.\nAll in all, a great game and i have only played some of the campaign so far. If you are sick of the usual shooters and would like something like... Day of Defeat meet Left for Dead then this is the game for you.\nRather addictive, just make sure you are wearing headphones or have your sound down or people will think you are speaking in satanic tongues. The voice overlay is... rather frightening. Think Silent Hill... meets... well... Satanic worship meets Bill Nighy.

reviewText:
This unambitious shooter sets itself appart in just being as simple and ridiculously great as it's name. It's like Left 4 Dead or Killing Floor, but with torrents of gore and specially emphatic of having a good aim.

Gunplay it's great, weapons feel alright, are all unlocked from the start and it's just a blast to play it in coop. The online is pretty much alive, don't know if it's because the deal price tough. Both controls with joy and k+M work pretty well. It may get a little samey but that's something you can take for granted in the zombie shooter genre.

There's not a lot to say about a game as simple as this, but it went for a simple objective and did it great.

If you liked both of those previous games, you can't go wrong with this one.

reviewText: Really fun game to play if you are searching for an entertaining sniper vs zombie experience. The story is simple, you are in the middle of a zombie apocalypse during WWII and you have to survive and take care of the undead. Nice graphics, cool kill-cam and good gameplay. You can play campaign (solo or co-op) and orde mode (facing endless waves of zombies). I suggest to play with friends to enjoy a very nice co-op experience. Recommended!

reviewText:
First things first, this is the only version of Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army that should be sold. Having the first two installments as individual packages not only narrows the amount of players in multiplayer, but also divides the market. I had previously purchased Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie, and I thought this would have all three as separate games. It's actually all three packed into one. The improvements are notable, however, it still seems unfair to those who bought the first games already.

This game is pretty damn fun, and for the amount of enjoyment it has given me alone I'd recommend this. Even if you own the previous two games already, this one is worth picking up for the modifications in the gore system, and all three campaigns in one. There is a Horde mode I haven't played much of, and so far it didn't seem to offer the same excitement that the campaign does, but I suppose I should hold off on judging that aspec of the game.

If you like similar games as Killing Floor, this one would easily be among your favorites. Mindless slaughter, although I will say the hitboxes do matter. So not so mindless as you should choose where you shoot your enemies. Head is most effective but you can dismember basically an entire zombie before you put it down. Chop off its legs, its arms, watch it crawl around for awhile, then pop it in the head.

With the remastered editions of the first two, you can really tell that they did in fact put some effort into them with the lighting and the fact the zombies are a lot harder to kill than before.

In Nazi Zombie Army 1 and 2 you could take an SMG to the zombies and mow them down, in this one the most you'll do is take out one and maybe a couple other zombie's helmets.

Overall, its a fun game that adds a lot of variety to the original experience!

reviewText:
Single player mode is very fun and can be brutally hard at times.

It does however improve your scope skills, you have to be accurate fast and really plan your positions.

Plus later on you find the neead to plant mines strategically and use grenades, dynamite absolutely vital later on.

Also using fixed machine gun nests can be the only thing that stops the horde overwhelming you.

Shooting warlock zombies that revive the dead first and Generals that spawn waves are just some of the boss enemies you face.

And the jumping zombies that bounce between positions after every shot are fun to kill too.

Then there are the Flame bosses who raise hordes of flame zombies to swarm you and are a ♥♥♥♥♥ to kill.

The list goes on and im still playing it so have yet to see them all. Think Left For Dead 2, with head shots a must, far better graphics and a better storyline...plus it has Nazi Hitler and Nazi zombies FFS. AAA+

reviewText: I have to say that I believe this game to be one of the most interesting FPS I have ever played. From the name and the advertising of the game is not hard to figure that this game has its action set in the last days of the Third Reich where a deluded Hitler has created an army of zombies. The visual quality is great and it makes the player realise not only the horrors of war but also that he is going to have some fun. With 16 characters and a horde mode it is already bringing something extra into the offer, plus if you haven't played the previous games you have all three of them in the package. The music is straight to the point and enhances the situations. The creators have also given you the option of playing the campaign or the horde mode into co-op, in total being four players and for the things not to get boring the number of enemies is increased.\n\nBut there are some negative aspects which are worth mentioning. If you are a fan of games which have a complex story, this is not a game for you as it can turn up pretty boring because the characters do not speak and therefore there is no dialogue, just some recorded tapes in safehouses which give you extra details about the plotline and how the situation has turned from worse to living nightmare. Having played this game quite much I totally recommend it. For me it is 8.5/10.

One of the best zom zom games!

The game is very hard at the easiest difficulty but once you get past all of that, it's not that bad. In other words, get it and don't ask questions!

reviewText:
Sniper Elite meets Left 4 Dead, in all of the best ways to make a great tongue-in-cheek zombie shooter.
3rd-person/marksmanship focused shooting we all love from Sniper Elite & only a headshot will reward you with a kill on most conventional baddies; where the squad bassed mechanics and level layouts are fresh from the Left 4 Dead build. All in all it makes for a rather fun, fast-paced, and often intense shooter that is best played with friends - as the more people you have in gamne - THE MORE ZOMBIES YOU GET TO SLAY! =D

Nothing to really gripe about off-hand, but it's also nothing revolutionary by any means; Solid 8/10 as a fun game with familiar mechanics served up with a nice dash of Johnnys Seasoning-Salt to mix things up.

Remember - Until the head is gone, the threat lives on.

reviewText:
The game plays great. Only one I have found in the staff side of Rebellion Support is worthy of comment. Don't assume your going to play this game and reach for the star of First Place. There is a serious bug in their database that they cannot figure out. I managed to get to that star, and fall over the edge with a negative 2.1 billion point glitch.

I had to go an unusual route to get the Rebellion staff to wake up, hats off to Paul for kicking them in the pants and getting them to answer my request after 2 months.

I had a goal - now I am not too sure I want to try to dig myself out of an existing hole and climbe up that ladder twice as high.

The game over all plays pretty decent. There are a few bugs here and there, but overall the game is OK. A team of 4 can have a blast in most situations. take advantage of your surroundings when the time is ripe. There is a coop campaign, which seems very short, and a Horde mode which lacks a good selection of maps.  These can be played on a variety of difficulty levels, whether coop or solo.

I have a unique situation, to become #1 of nearly 200,000 players who have tried this game. I think the respect for such commitment should come from within the manufacturing of the product at hand. Don't shove me an inferior product, then thell me the issue cannot be recreated or fixed. Its not only my issue, there are at least 6 others in the same boat. Its a damn shame support is slow to respond and certain internals of the game is broke.

reviewText:
This review may be subject to change, as I have only played this game for a short time. Just in the time that I have played, which is 0.7 hrs at this time, there is a bug that should not be attempted. If you are playing full screen, and you minimize your game, [Alt]+[Tab], you will force the mouse on the corner of the screen and when you click, the game will minimize again. You'll have to force close the game at that point. I haven't played a lot, but the game is fun. Just wish the zombies were further away when spawning.

Update.
6.2 hrs played and this game is proving to be rather challenging and there are some free shot moments. Melee kills don't count towards your multiplier. Noticed blood footprints up the walls and ceiling in one building. I've been playing this game on Ultra settings using a GTX 660 with 2Gb VRAM. 99% of the game will run smooth without hickups, depending on what is going on. Not sure if just a little more power is needed or just more VRAM, but the game performs very well. It's not too demanding, so the video card exceeds recommended, but just a hair shallow of Optimal.

Update #2.
After completing this game, 21 hrs, the game has been both fun and challenging. I enjoyed it. Was disappointed about the ending, didn't realize it was the end until the credits. I was hoping for more, that's how much I enjoyed it. I've had a second monitor plugged in while playing and for some reason, performance is diminished. When the second monitor goes dark, the game runs better. It's when the second monitor is unplugged that there are more frame issues, but how then do you manage that? The challenges of this game are really impressive. Just on single player I had fun. I'm eager to play this with other people. If you own the older versions, I do recommend getting this game for cooperative play. I did catch an easter egg on one level involving a castle. My only disappointment is the Prologues not autoplaying at their appropriate times during the game. I didn't skip any scenes since I had never seen or played the original versions. Now to try the game on more difficult settings. Maybe later, I'll increase the spawn of zombies.

reviewText:
While zombies and nazis do get repetative, chapter 1 and 3 are a blast.
If you know your horror films every level contains a nod to a different one. Lots of secrets and easter eggs to discover.

If this game played more with the environment and had more melee options it would rival Resident Evil 4 in the level of fun i extracted from it. On sale its perfectly priced.

The sniping aspect is wildly exaggerated, if your rifle is not high velocitiy it has massive drop and takes a dozen head shots to kill the MG zombies.
High velocity, however, will rip through a line of undead which is far more entertaining. Why pick anything else?

Side arms suffer from some balance issues also, the polish smg and revolver hands down outclasses any other option.

And of course you get a show down with the fuhrer in hell. What more could you ask for?

reviewText:
If you like zombie games, then this is for you.

If you expect this to be like CoD Zombies or L4D, then don't.

Zombie Army Trilogy is a a brutally hard sniper shooter packed to the brim with huge hordes of disgusting Nazi zombies that will overwhelm you and kill you very fast. Just to turn the difficulty up a few more notches, they also only die from headshots- unless you utterly destroy the body, they will simply resurrect.

It has campaign and horde modes, but I recommend playing both in multiplayer. It's a lot funner (and easier) to have people alongside to watch your back and help out, as well as provide witty banter.

The game itself is heavily polished, with great graphics and controls, a dark and tense atmosphere, and fun gameplay.

reviewText:
shots kinda feel delayed and laggy. Its not the most polished or interesting horde mode zombie co-op shooter. But it does its job.

I wouldnt recommend it cuz there are better games out there with similar things doing for them.

I will give you an example, do you want a parkour game? Mirrors edge, one game

But a zombie co-op shooter on pc: Killing floor 2, call of duty zombies, Left for dead 2, all of which are better then this game, granted they are in first person. But does it matter??

This game has no originality, it copies many things from other games, and shooting is not that satisfiying or the enviroments are not that varied to begin with.
6/10 not worth a buy when you can play better ones.

Port vise, its a good one. But frame rate often dips bellow when there are too many alpha effects on the screen, seems similar to killing floor 2 in terms of optimization, which isnt that good.

reviewText:
Frustrating zombie shooter game. Don't believe the hype.

Negative aspects of the game:
1. Swaying crosshairs. Unless you hold your breath to steady the crosshairs, you find yourself most of the time playing" prediction with it.
2. Uses quick match system so you have no choice of hosts to connect to. It would be nice to select from multiple hosts instead of the game randomly selecting it for you.
3. Shotgun seems like the only effective close quarter crowd control weapon.
4. The CTRL aim (hip fire) is absurdly inaccurate. The crosshairs for your secondary and sidearm are spread out that it's a task to perform precision shots. The shots you perform are more prediction than precision.
5. The hits on the zombies don't have that organic feel. It's like your shooting the wall. It reminds me of playing No More Room in Hell.

The Left for Dead add-on doesn't even compensate for the poor system of gameplay.

If you want a good zombie co-op game
date: get Killing Floor or Left 4 Dead."

reviewText:
I bought this back in March of this year, back then I could play solo and aim at the zombies. Since the Left 4 Dead characters were added a lot has changed for me!
Aim is all over the place, the rifle which is your primary weapon , looks up at the sky not at the target, if I'm lucky enough to manoeuvre the scope to a target's head , 9/10 times  I will still miss even with focus aim,
because it continues to shake . This also uses up lots of ammo in the process .
The Side arm or Pistol's aim is gone too, I aim, the crosshair is on the zombie's head , then I fire , crosshair moves to the left of target , so I end up shooting air , not good when being attacked.
The Secondary weapon, the Machine gun, for me in this situation is the best one, but you can't find secondary ammo all the time .
The L4D update IMO has upped the difficulty too, especially on Solo mode. There are missions you could not play solo anymore.
CO-OP is a lot of fun, but if your the one who's weapons don't work, not fun for your team lol.
CO-OP also has it issues , either the host being booted to lobby or some of your team will be.
I also think some of the old missions have been removed from the game, I remember not far into the game, playing a cemetery mission where you had to clear it of zombies ,that is not there now.
Thinking that maybe the aiming had something to do with my controller, I played some sniper elite and headshots for days, so the problem is this game.  Would I recommend this game as it now is? No I wouldn't . If your thinking of buying it try out a friends copy first or buy from where you can get a refund.

reviewText: This game is a MAJOR RIP-OFF! Of their previous games' maps AND of your money. They even inherited the same bug, where the stage doesn' t lead anywhere. reviewText:
I expected a shooter and got a tunnel-vision walking simulator with illogical placement of physical barriers (oh no I cannot get over that 1 foot high piece of wood; oh the game made that bit of air impassable;...), repetitive wave-spawning zombies and about as much immersion as trying to bath in a bottlecap.

Maybe it just wasn't my kind of game, but it seemed like it did everything wrong that modern games tend to do right, no matter if they are AAA or cheaply produced. Lots of the old vices" of game design make a grand come-back in this title and I have to say I did hope they had died for good.

Well
date: I guess those are the undead that have risen that this game is truly all about..."

reviewText: On the fence about whether or not to reccommend this game. It really seems like fun, but one of the things that sucks about PC gaming is never knowing how well the game is going to place on your PC. You read the reccommended specs and more than meet them, watch gameplay footage and compare the the resolution of the graphics and mechanics vs another game on your PC and try to make a reasonable judgement and fall completely on your face. There's nothing terribly complex or high end in this game, watching videos I thought, oh about resident evil 4 level game mechanics and graphics, I should be able to at the very least play the game smoothly on the lowest settings, but alas no.  So much stutter and lag. I really want to enjoy the game and it seems like fun, but most people probably won't have a high end enough PC to be able to enjoy it so I can't reccommend it.

reviewText: You kill zombies with WWII-era weapons. There are lots and lots of zombies. What sets this game apart from more traditional" zombie shooters is the ubiquitous sniper rifle. What sets the sniper rifle in this game apart from other games with sniper rifles is that you can aim without scoping. That's right. There's a button to scope in and a button to aim without.\n\nZombies - there are lots and   lots	  of zombies. If enjoyed the running gun battles with zombies in State of Decay
date:
you'll have a good time here.

Four-player coop - it works out pretty well.

reviewText: The gameplay doesn't change one bit from the first ten minutes until the end.  What kept me playing so long was the graphics, which are quite lovely, and the slow-motion, head-'sploding kill cam stuff.   Ultimately, after 18 hours, I have no wish to play it anymore.  I did boot it up when they introduced the Left for Dead characters but that was hardly a big update.  Why aren't there more guns?  That would be the single easiest and most effective aspect to change to actually add some form of variety to the gameplay, instead of having five rifles that all feel the same, and five machine guns that all feel the same, and three handguns you'll never use because two are just a tad better.\n\nSo, fun for a while, and not without potential, but burns out fast.

reviewText:
Not quite as dynamic as I expected it to be. And, most importantly, the co-op multiplayer is downright empty.

The rifles feel more or less the same (some have better zoom or faster rate of fire), there is no heavy hitting option with a lower ammo supply, for example. Yes, the original game is all about landing long-distance headshots, but this one is about routinely killing lots of zombies.

There are basically four types of enemies - the common zombie - takes 2-3 shots to the chest to die, the skeleton - dies to a single shot or kick, the suicide bomber - runs at you, but drops dead from single shot and the machinegunner - takes quite a few headshots to kill while you backpedal around.

The tasks. again, all rely on killing everything. I have not seen any stealth segments requiring you to kill enemies only with headshots or any situations that would require strategy. It's all about shooting center mass. And there are a lot of targets to shoot.

If you want a good experience you should bring many friends and few expectations.

reviewText:
A twist on other zombie survival genre titles, that challenges and satisfies. Successfully combined elements of Left for Dead and Sniper Elite make for a fun and rewarding experience. The game can be equally fun solo as it can be with others playing with you, allowing you to test your skills against multiple campaign missions; each getting progressivly more challenging. Although some areas were difficult to solo, I managed to complete all missions available, and what fun it was! I reccomend anyone who is a fan of Left or Dead or Sniper Elite to pick it up. It is an excellent package that provides many hours of longevity.

Additional Note:
The game does suffer from poor optimization in certain areas. Although pretty minor, they will be noticible on most configurations.

reviewText:
This game is a huge ripoff!! It says there are three games... no there isn't. It's more episodes. Highly overpriced, I mean to the point of how are they getting away with this false advertising? Screw this company...

IT IS ONE GAME. Don't be fooled by the text... because you think there would be some regulation and someone could sue them, or you could get a refund for the blatant lies. But you can't... because it's only 30$ when it should have been 5$

The gameplay isn't great either, it's not the worst but it isn't done very well. Ammo is scarce, it has redundant weapons that don't show you anything different and barely any difference in them anyway. Some are so overpowered it is pointless to use anything else. Ammo is the most annoying part of the game, they give you 3 weapons though so you never run out, it just sucks to use anything else. So the game winds up being annoying to play when you have to use a weapon you don't like. Not like there is any reason to play the game because there is not much of a story, all you do is kill zombies and hitler shows up and you kill him. The End. They really like Hitler stuff lately.

Really pisses me off when they can lie about games and not give refunds. Absolutely disgusted by this.

They are (Un-Bias) THE best zombie games in existance.

reviewText:
Do you enjoy playing L4D/L4D2? If yes, then this game is for you.

The thing I like the most is how much more real it feels, and the headshots required to kill the zombies. Unlike in L4D/L4D2 where you can run in all guns blazing and get the mission over and done with, this actually requires a bit more skill and effort, and I think it's great! It takes a little bit of getting used to, but the function keys are almost the same as L4D/L4D2. The only different thing that took getting used to was the walking around, I always bump into things, but after a few minutes of playing, it gets easier.

Also suggest playing it with a group of 3-4 people. The more people you have, the more zombies you get! Just way more fun with more people in my opinion. I prefer to play games with others anyway! Makes the game more enjoyable. :)

Definitely recommend this game to anyone who is bored of playing L4D/L4D2.

reviewText:
Better than the earlier releases of NZA 1 and 2 but buyers be warned...


The third game is too hard for one player even on the lowest difficulty, there are too many (specifically in the final missions) where theres no room to manuever and too many zombies even if its set to 1 player amount of zombies.

The first two chapters in the trilogy are fairly easy and fun to play with much more enhancements, changes and content additions, plus it's less demanding on low end PCs than the first releases.

If you are planning on buying the trilogy then I'd suggest getting some friends to play it with you. Solo is a whole different ballpark than coop. If you don't have any friends to play it with you then Id suggest not bothering with the last missions on the third campaign.

reviewText:
This game really is something worth buying and here's why:

Pros
+ coop as well as single player possible
+ nice variety in weaponry (rifles, pistols, smg's, explosives) with characteristic properties
+ all three campaigns with part I and II nicely re-done (many maps and nice variety)
+ increase in difficulty compared to NZA I/II
+ new enemies/variety in enemies
+ boss fights
+ 2nd WW zombie game :D
+ 8 playable characters
+ classic Sniper Elite killcam
+ dismemberment
+ atmosphere
And the list goes on and on...

Cons
- hit box issues
- random fps drops

I highly recommend this game for everyone who likes WW2, slaughtering zombies and FPS!

8/10 because of those hit box issues which can decide between life and death...

reviewText:
3 co-op campaigns to play with your friends + horde mode. Me + 2 friends made it through the first campaign in probably 8 hours on Marksman difficulty (aka Normal).

It's totally worth the price of admission, but there are some annoyances:

Unreasonable inaccuracy on secondary weapons and pistols. Even firing one round at a time while aiming, non-rifles are crazy inaccurate and it feels weird and artificial. You can't accurately headshot something 2 meters away with an SMG while standing perfectly still, aiming, and firing only one bullet.

1 friend crashed out a few times in ~8 hours, though the rest of us had no issues.

I wish you could see stats for weapons / explosives. I can't tell much difference between any weapons besides mag-size and firing speed.

reviewText:
TL;DR Version: It's a fun game, but waiting for a sale wouldn't hurt.

I like to think of Zombie Army Trilogy as an arcade-style game. It's fun to sink time into, but don't expect innovation or reinvention here. With that said, though, I do think it's a game worth picking up if you like these kind of games or are even curious as to how the game is.

I didn't have any performance issues like other reviewers did, so I can't complain there. But, the graphics are pretty much the same as the other Zombie Army games. Though, what good are graphics if the game isn't good?

As a game, it's a fun experience that is even better when played with friends. Going back to the arcade comparison, you are scored at the end of each mission. You can rack up points by slaying the undead in various ways. You can also find collectible gold bars and bottles for your end-mission results. The simplistic yet fun gameplay, and the pre-game loadout screen make getting such scores even more fun.

One thing I personally wasn't sure of was the soundtrack. I don't know what exactly, but some sound queues and songs just didn't seem to fit in with the game. Just a personal grievence, though.

If you plan on buying this game, it would not hurt to wait for it to go on sale.

Like I said, the game has this charming arcade feel that I love, but that could be an aquired taste. I'd say if your interested in this game, pick it up (or wait 'til it goes on sale), grab some friends, and have a good time.

10/10 would MLG collateral headshot 4 zombies again.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This game is totally awesome! When I got the 1st Zombie Army a couple of years ago I used to have trouble doing headshots because of the way the Zombies move back and forth. After playing through Sniper Elite 3 I seem to have gotten a lot better. I use the 3rd difficulty level. On long shots it actually shows you where to aim. I looked for a way to turn it off but I couldn't find one. It actually helps because there are places where you have more than one snipers you have to deal with at a time. There was plenty of ammo and more exploding barrels than I needed to get rid of masses of Zombies. I recommend this game to any Sniper Elite or Zombie fans. This game just became on of my very best games and I have over 100 games. The only way it could have been better is if you could save the game at will like you can with Sniper Elite 3. One of the best things about this series for me is that I bought some of the DLCs with extra weapons. I play single player only. These rifles are available in the solo mode also, as well as Multiplayer.  A bit of advice. Don't try to just hold a position! Keep moving around! When they start getting too close just run away for a bit and then stop and pick them off as they come to you. There is plenty of explosive material laying around to kill them with also.

reviewText:
When i first heard that Rebellion was releasing the third game in a pack with the first two but not on its own, i was extremely disappointed. Though when i saw that if you had one or both of the previous games the price was reduced by a third or two, which went to lengths to sate that disappointment. Then i was worried about the gameplay. I play on a laptop that was very far from being made for gaming and the first two games ran like ♥♥♥♥ on it. I loved the first two i just wish there had been better gameplay quality. I started up the first game in the pack and was immediately shocked as to how much better it ran! Not only that, but there was far more zombie variety! There are few things in these games that i thought could be improved, and this is definitely an improvement on all fronts.


Gameplay: 27/30
Graphics: 7/10
Replay Value: 6/10
Zombie Killing Fun: 50/50
Overall: 90/100

reviewText: You can't go wrong with Zombie Army Trilogy if you are a seasoned Sniper Elite veteran or new to the series. If you haven't played the first two Nazi Zombie Army games, don't bother, just play this version instead. The original two games are included, with some nice improvements. But if you have already played them, this is still worth picking up as you'll get improved versions of the first two, the 3rd installment, and the new horde mode.\n\nThe game works fine as a single-player experience, but it really shines in co-op. My friends and I have played the first two and jumped on this new release. Take that into consideration though when purchasing and consider talking some friends into attacking the undead hordes with you. It definitely gets grindy if you are looking to 100% the achievements, but is still a fun co-op experience.

reviewText:
Rebellion's offering of Nazi Zombie killing is an immensely satisfying experience that will bring much pleasure to any fan of the undead.

The campaign has 15 missions split up into 3 Chapters with the first two being NZA 1 & 2 respectively. The first two chapters have been updated with better graphics. Playing them is fun even though they show their age. The third chapter is the main attraction of the package and is the best of the 3.

The gore has been fantasticly done and is very enjoyable blowing bits off zombies, especially blowing a zombie in half which I found highly entertaining. X-Ray killcam is as good as ever and adds to the feel that you're actually shooting them.

Gameplay is a mixture from Sniper Elite V2, 3 and both the NZA games. One thing I noticed was that the SMG's feel less powerful, taking me at least two shots to blow off a zombies head compared to one shot from the previous games often resulting in having to resort to the shotgun for a decent chance of survival. Bit of a shame in my eyes as I really enjoyed using SMG's in the aforementioned NZA games. What is a shame is that the cover system has been completley removed which leaves you vunerable to snipers and super elites, but is slightly lessened by the stomp feature which will certainly save your hide!

Hoard mode is a complete blast, highly enjoyable and better when played with friends. Similar to COD's zombie mode with the exception of being more of a challenge rather than just a simple run and gun. A very welcome addition that will provide much entertainment.

The enemies are what I personally feel make this game. The snipers add the challenge of getting them while trying to deal with the other undead. The elites are more dangerous being able to tear apart your team in seconds if not careful, more so with the Chainsaw Elite which proves a challenge and requires thought before taking him on. Skeletons compliment the bog standard zombies being very easy to deal with (a swift kick deals with them!)

In summary, is this game worth it? Hell yes! The experience is better in co-op than solo. Generally a well rounded package that will provide hours of fun. Kudos to Rebellion for their efforts in producing this game.

reviewText:
Say what you will about the Nazi Zombie Army games, but I personally think they're an absolute hoot.  The original two titles in the Sniper Elite spinoff series had their ups and downs, but Zombie Army Trilogy takes all the best elements and throws them in a blender, giving them better play mechanics, better graphics and a much more enjoyable overall experience.  Sure, this looks and plays mostly like the originals, but you'll quickly find that a lot has changed, and for the better.  Zombie models are more varied and unique, and nearly all get much better coats of paint.  Enemy balancing has been improved, giving you a fair shot against opportunistic zombie snipers, while toning down the strength of enemies like skeletons, to make them more realistic.  One of the best new features of the game is the good ol' boot that you use to kick enemies away.  No longer a means to give you some breathing room, the kick is now a damaging move that gives you an edge during combat.  A single kick will knock a zombie back (with some enhanced physics, I might add) and chance a kill, or you can kick a zombie when he's down to finish him off by footballing his head across the pavement.  It's a great feature.  The presentation of the game is now more polished, and feels more like a story with appropriate titling and captioning during cutscenes where needed.

Also introduced in Z.A.T. is a new Horde mode, similar to the survival challenge mode seen in Sniper Elite V3.  Playing in the church was a game of run and shoot, until later levels started packing the cramped hallways with armored and MG42 zombies, forcing me to run every few seconds.  Definitely a difficult mode!  As usual, weapons and tactics play a huge part in your survival.  Setting traps at appropriate locations can maximize your chances of survival, and knowing the layout of your surroundings is absolutely crucial, as zombie hordes can emerge from any direction.

Sure, it's a simplistic and potentially repetitive title, but I love the Nazi Zombie Army games, and Trilogy" brings them together in the best version of the game so far.  I haven't yet hit the third chapter of the game
date: but I'm looking forward to seeing what's to come!  Here's to hoping that the game sells well
recommended: and Multiplayer gets a shot in the arm.  There's far too few people playing the original two games
hoursPlayed: and that's a shame.  Co-op on this game is a blast!\n\nDefinitely a YES for me."

reviewText:
Zombie Army Trilogy is a solo and co op zombie horror action game that contains the original 2 Sniper Elite spinoff nazi zombie army games and continues with a 3rd chapter.  This is supposedly a new engine but the only difference I've noticed is the inclusion of dismemberment and reduced strength of submachine guns.

There are 15 lengthy levels that takes Karl, the star of Sniper Elite V2, and 3 other playable characters through Zombie cursed Nazi Germany.

Pros:
==================
+Intense gory zombie action; maintains the formula of the older 2 cult-classic titles with new content and improved gore effects
+LOTS of zombies to shoot at
+Variety of elite or guardian" zombies
date:
ranging from machine gun-wielding brutes to chainsaw-swinging maniacs
+Amazing graphical detail in the level environments
+Great atmosphere
+Works well for solo and co op play
+The 80's synth-style soundtrack compliments the horror vibe nicely
==================

Cons:
==================
-Unnecessarily long "survive the assult/seige" sections feel like padding
-There are a few frustratingly and punishingly difficult fights (especially in the final level) involving HORDES of elite bullet--spongy (and sometimes endless respanwning) zombies in narrow close quarters
-The submachine guns feel less powerful than the separate NZA games
==================

I would give this game an 7/10 rating.

==========
Final thoughts
==========
Based on my Pros and Cons I would have given it a 8/10
recommended: but when I have second thoughts about my playthrough
hoursPlayed: I am not exaggerating when I say the final level contains frustrating difficulty spikes that are near torture.  Granted
voteText: the bigger the challenge the greater the satisfaction upon beating it

votesTotal: 2015) to get the most bang for your buck.  You will have fun playing it alone and with your friends for a while with this one."

reviewText:
The first 2 felt like amusing side projects to Sniper Elite, but this one definitely feels like a polished game.  Details have been added to the existing campaigns, controls have been tightened significantly, and best of all in the 6 hours I've played so far there were no crashes at all, unlike the first one.

PROS
Horde mode
Polished campaign (added level details, etc)
Fun sniping cam
Big discount if you own 1 & 2
Much better lobby system than the first time
Varied enemies
8 characters now, 4 men 4 women
Kick/stomp added
Realtime achievement progress

CONS
Only 5 Horde maps (are they making more? I don't know.)
No war journal for overall stats
4 players max; would have liked 5 but that's personal preference

I bought the first 2 right off the bat, and this one was a no-brainer. Super fun game.

reviewText:
So, I'm not really one for writing reviews, but I decided to give it a go, since I believe this spin-off series deserve some recognition and get a larger playerbase. I have played the first two ZA games, but not the main series of SE, but I will try to compare with what I know.

Let's begin with the pros"

-In the main SE series you only have a few basic weapons available. If you want more weapons and maps to play
date: you have to buy every single DLC. In the ZA spin-off series
recommended: there are no DLC. Every single weapon and map are available from the get-go.\n-New characters: Each of the four playable characters now have a female counterpart. Perfect if you're a gamer girl or if your favorite character is taken and you are ok to settle with the next-best. These are not rule 63 version of the characters however: They wear similar clothing but have their own faces
hoursPlayed: hairstyles and character backgrounds.\n-The full campaigns from the first two games plus new third story all in one game. No more swapping between ZA 1 & 2 in order to find a game to play.\n-New "Horde" Mode: Every game of this genre needs a survival mode. Pick one of five maps where you fight against endless waves of increasing zombies for as long as you can. Three of these maps are based on areas from the first ZA game
voteText: the other two are completely original.\n-The previous two campaigns have been slightly remastered. By this I mean it uses the more polished graphics of ZAT and SE3 as well as the changes ZAT made to how some zombies work.\n-In conjunction with the above point
helpfulPercent: we have some tweaking done with zombies. Whether this sounds like a pro or con is up to you: Zombies such as the burning ones summoned by a Fire Elite are no longer simply standard zombies on fire: They are faster and turn into ash upon killed or coming into contact with you (which deals dmg to the player) but are all killed with a single hit from any weapon. Skeletons have been given a visual update
votesHelpful: they are now more detailed
votesTotal: but they are also weaker. They can be killed with a single kick. The exclusion is the new armored skeletons who appear in late medieval or early renaissance plate armor: It takes several hits with standard weapons to chip it off
votesFunny: but once the heart is exposed
commentsCount: they can be one-shot like all other skeletons.\n-New types of zombies: everything from standard zombies with Lugers and MP40's and an inherent Stormtrooper accuracy (geddid? Nazis - Stormtroopers?) to the aforementioned skeletal knights or the weaksauce Armored Elite all the way up to the horrifying Chainsaw Elite (this guy makes all the other elites feel normal).\n-Tweaked combat mechanics: You can now dismember zombies
column16: making them easy to pick off when they crawl at you without legs or lash out at you with little stumps instead of arms. SMG's and the shotgun has had their dmg "nerfed" in order to balance it out with the improved kick mechanic: Kicking is now much more important and usable: you can kick all standard zombies down and then kick again to stomp their heads. This is often more prudent as it can be more time and ammo efficient to pick off stragglers or escape from clusters. It's also the most efficient way to deal with skeletons.\n-Improved arsenal: No more swapping between grenades. Instead of two stielhandgranates and frag grenades each
column17: you know can carry up to four stiels instead. The shotgun has been nerfed down to the level of the other secondaries
column18: but it and the Webley revolver have been added to the standard loadout. Yay! The Panzerfaust and the Preacher remains as the biggest dmg-dealers to be found across the maps.\n\nBut of course there is no completely perfect game
column19: so here are the "cons" that I feel needs to be addressed\n\n-The inability to "cover". In the other ZA and SE games

reviewText:
The cult horror shooter series comes to an apocalyptic conclusion with an epic new third chapter, a heart-pumping new horde mode, and remastered editions of the best-selling Nazi Zombie Army 1 & 2.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3onad6717s4

In the dying flames of World War II, Hitler has unleashed one final, unholy gamble – a legion of undead super soldiers that threatens to overwhelm the whole of Europe. Fight alone or team up to save humanity from the zombie menace in this apocalyptic third-person shooter!

Battle through THREE epic campaigns across 15 demon-infested missions. Play solo or fight back to back in online co-op for 2-4 players. Dare you take on one of the most intense and challenging third-person shooters in gaming?

Face gruesome enemies with iconic weaponry and powerful explosives. Dismember the undead to give yourself a fighting chance, and experience every putrid lung burst, every rotten bone shatter with the infamous X-ray Kill Camera. - Recommended!

reviewText:
TL;DR Version: It's a fun game, but waiting for a sale wouldn't hurt.

I like to think of Zombie Army Trilogy as an arcade-style game. It's fun to sink time into, but don't expect innovation or reinvention here. With that said, though, I do think it's a game worth picking up if you like these kind of games or are even curious as to how the game is.

I didn't have any performance issues like other reviewers did, so I can't complain there. But, the graphics are pretty much the same as the other Zombie Army games. Though, what good are graphics if the game isn't good?

As a game, it's a fun experience that is even better when played with friends. Going back to the arcade comparison, you are scored at the end of each mission. You can rack up points by slaying the undead in various ways. You can also find collectible gold bars and bottles for your end-mission results. The simplistic yet fun gameplay, and the pre-game loadout screen make getting such scores even more fun.

One thing I personally wasn't sure of was the soundtrack. I don't know what exactly, but some sound queues and songs just didn't seem to fit in with the game. Just a personal grievence, though.

If you plan on buying this game, it would not hurt to wait for it to go on sale.

Like I said, the game has this charming arcade feel that I love, but that could be an aquired taste. I'd say if your interested in this game, pick it up (or wait 'til it goes on sale), grab some friends, and have a good time.

10/10 would MLG collateral headshot 4 zombies again.

reviewText:
Damn good game. Killing Nazi has always been a pleasure, but Nazi zombies, boy, twice the fun.
How can you not buy this when you can kill Zombie Hitler.

Pros:
1. If you love to kill Nazi, this is it.
2. If you love to kill zombies, this is it.
3. Smooth control, good physics for bullet path
4. Good varieties of sniper rifles

Cons:
1. Secondary weapon (SMG/Handgun) are not powerful (Some might see this as a Pro as this is called SNIPER elite)
2. Story might be too linear for some, although to me it's perfect (no brainer, nazi zombie massacre)
3. Some achievements (Goldbar/Blood bottles) are way too hard to obtain on the first try, or 2nd try
4. Campaign can be overly repetitive (low chance of playing it through again, unless with different people)

I haven't tried online multiplayers (public), all of it was with my brother so I can't give you too much insights to that component.

Overall, this is one hell of a good game to play, 49.99 might be steep for someone, so wait until it goes on sale, or if your fingers are just itching to shoot some nazi zombie, just pull the trigger, you won't regret spending that money.

reviewText:
Say what you will about the Nazi Zombie Army games, but I personally think they're an absolute hoot.  The original two titles in the Sniper Elite spinoff series had their ups and downs, but Zombie Army Trilogy takes all the best elements and throws them in a blender, giving them better play mechanics, better graphics and a much more enjoyable overall experience.  Sure, this looks and plays mostly like the originals, but you'll quickly find that a lot has changed, and for the better.  Zombie models are more varied and unique, and nearly all get much better coats of paint.  Enemy balancing has been improved, giving you a fair shot against opportunistic zombie snipers, while toning down the strength of enemies like skeletons, to make them more realistic.  One of the best new features of the game is the good ol' boot that you use to kick enemies away.  No longer a means to give you some breathing room, the kick is now a damaging move that gives you an edge during combat.  A single kick will knock a zombie back (with some enhanced physics, I might add) and chance a kill, or you can kick a zombie when he's down to finish him off by footballing his head across the pavement.  It's a great feature.  The presentation of the game is now more polished, and feels more like a story with appropriate titling and captioning during cutscenes where needed.

Also introduced in Z.A.T. is a new Horde mode, similar to the survival challenge mode seen in Sniper Elite V3.  Playing in the church was a game of run and shoot, until later levels started packing the cramped hallways with armored and MG42 zombies, forcing me to run every few seconds.  Definitely a difficult mode!  As usual, weapons and tactics play a huge part in your survival.  Setting traps at appropriate locations can maximize your chances of survival, and knowing the layout of your surroundings is absolutely crucial, as zombie hordes can emerge from any direction.

Sure, it's a simplistic and potentially repetitive title, but I love the Nazi Zombie Army games, and Trilogy" brings them together in the best version of the game so far.  I haven't yet hit the third chapter of the game
date: but I'm looking forward to seeing what's to come!  Here's to hoping that the game sells well
recommended: and Multiplayer gets a shot in the arm.  There's far too few people playing the original two games
hoursPlayed: and that's a shame.  Co-op on this game is a blast!\n\nDefinitely a YES for me."
voteText: March 6, 2015

reviewText:
Zombie Army Trilogy is a solo and co op zombie horror action game that contains the original 2 Sniper Elite spinoff nazi zombie army games and continues with a 3rd chapter.  This is supposedly a new engine but the only difference I've noticed is the inclusion of dismemberment and reduced strength of submachine guns.

There are 15 lengthy levels that takes Karl, the star of Sniper Elite V2, and 3 other playable characters through Zombie cursed Nazi Germany.

Pros:
==================
+Intense gory zombie action; maintains the formula of the older 2 cult-classic titles with new content and improved gore effects
+LOTS of zombies to shoot at
+Variety of elite or guardian" zombies
date:
ranging from machine gun-wielding brutes to chainsaw-swinging maniacs
+Amazing graphical detail in the level environments
+Great atmosphere
+Works well for solo and co op play
+The 80's synth-style soundtrack compliments the horror vibe nicely
==================

Cons:
==================
-Unnecessarily long "survive the assult/seige" sections feel like padding
-There are a few frustratingly and punishingly difficult fights (especially in the final level) involving HORDES of elite bullet--spongy (and sometimes endless respanwning) zombies in narrow close quarters
-The submachine guns feel less powerful than the separate NZA games
==================

I would give this game an 7/10 rating.

==========
Final thoughts
==========
Based on my Pros and Cons I would have given it a 8/10
recommended: but when I have second thoughts about my playthrough
hoursPlayed: I am not exaggerating when I say the final level contains frustrating difficulty spikes that are near torture.  Granted
voteText: the bigger the challenge the greater the satisfaction upon beating it
helpfulPercent: but I really have no desire to play that level ever again
votesHelpful: zombie Hitler or not.\n\nI would recommend buying this game when it is on sale (such as now up til April 3
votesTotal: 2015) to get the most bang for your buck.  You will have fun playing it alone and with your friends for a while with this one."

reviewText:
This is truly a great game, especially when played with friends.

Good graphics, good controls, plenty of options to tweak. And best of all, it's a ton of fun.

The formula is simple enough but it doesn't get old. Shoot zombies in the head, rinse and repeat. Some of the set pieces are actually pretty cool and the environments are generally very-well designed.

Overall this is a complete no-brainer when it's on sale (currently 15 bucks), but I would gladly pay $50 for this kind of a game. Great entertainment and high replay-value. Buy this game.

reviewText:
Been searching for a game like this since the release of Left 4 dead and left 4 dead 2. A game which throws you into interesting levels that ooze atmosphere, riddled with explosive traps and secrets this is a game in which I could sink hours into.

Pros:
+atmospheric levels and great level design
+Fun gunplay
+Replayability for each level
+Option of a Horde mode
+Fun weither playing Single player or Multiplayer.
+X-ray camera is always satisfying
+Great enemy variety

Cons:
-Guns in each catagory feel pretty much the same. (Snipers all feel the same, sub machine guns all feel the same, only one shotgun not counting the Preacher which isn't a starting weapon, pistols except for the revolver feel the same as well.)
-Game does have a few nasty bugs
-Price when not on sale is quite high

That being said this is probably one of the best coop shooters out there, I would recommend this game full price to anyone who was a fan of the sniper series or has an irristible itch for a coop shooter, for everyone else, wait for a sale like I did.

reviewText:
WWII Sniper crossed with Nazi Zombies featuring X-Ray kill-cams.

I shot a zombie through the skull, popping out an eyeball and severing the spinal chord. Then in a second shot I broke three ribs, pierced a lung and destroyed the spinal column.

If gore is in your nature, this game is right up your alley. Also, if you like Nazi Zombies in CoD: Black Ops or L4D, then this game falls in line pretty well. Lots of chances for co-op gameplay through both the story and survival gameplay.

reviewText:
Not nearly done yet, but I have thoroughly enjoyed my time with this game so far.

Never played any of the Nazi Zombie Army games or Sniper Elite games before, but had my eye on this updated compilation pretty much since it came out, but finally got it on sale 33% off.

The gun play is tense and rewarding. The bullet cam feature, which shows your bullet in slow motion as it passes through an enemy on longer range kill shots, is extremely satisfying, as there are quite a few zombie movement patterns, and their heads don't stay level like in many shooters, they flex and bob, and this makes head shots feel like a great accomplishment, even when you're continually making them.

Strategy figures into the game a ton as well. The game regularly puts you in defense" type situations
date: where you're at a location and you just have to survive until all the enemies are dead
recommended: and in these situations use of non-typical weaponry

reviewText:
I paid $11+change for this in a sale four-pack.

Wander through ruined WW2 Berlin and environs (repurposed maps from the original Sniper Elite games), shooting NAZI ZOMBIES in the face with your sniper rifle of choice.  Should this prove dull, you can shoot NAZI ZOMBIES in the face with SMGs, ARs, pistols, or, if you are feeling particularly inventive, you can blow the NAZI ZOMBIES apart using grenades, trip mines, or other barrels of boom lying around the place.

If you're lonely, you can gang up with up to three other human players to destroy the NAZI ZOMBIES, just like Left 4 Dead.  Except that you're shooting NAZI ZOMBIES and not Infected, and there is no AI director to spam more hordes at you, making ZAT more methodical and, you know, snipery.

As a bonus, you occasionally get to see, in gruesome detail, what one of your nicer shots does to the innards of a NAZI ZOMBIE.  It usually involves multiple wisdom tooth removal via a 7.62mm chunk of lead.  Unlike ZAT's parent game, you aren't specifically told that you wiped out Johan's tonsils, kidneys, and left testicle with one shot, but Sniper Elite is all about being a psycho bell-tower wannabe and ZAT is all about graves registration.

Stuff like graphics controls blah blah blah are all fine.  My $11 was well spent.  I wish I had bought this prior to buying ZOMBI (for $20).  ZOMBI looked liked ♥♥♥ and pretended to have a story.  ZAT looks far better and cheerfully brushes the story" aside in favor of atmospheric 80s John Carpenter music.

I would have liked the game to let me know best score I've ever achieved on a level
date: rather than just display the my latest score.  Not showing this is a weird thing for what basically amounts to a score-attack game.\n\nThumbs up."
